title: Georgy Polkovnikov
text:
Georgy Petrovich Polkovnikov (<a href="March%207">March 7</a>, <a href="1883">1883</a>, Stanitsa Krivyanskaya, <a href="Don%20Host%20Oblast">Don Host Oblast</a> – March <a href="1918">1918</a>) was a <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian</a> military leader, commander–in–chief of the <a href="Petersburg%20Military%20District%20%28Russian%20Empire%29">Petrograd Military District</a> in September – October 1917, his last military rank was <a href="colonel">colonel</a>.
Biography.
Born into the family of a Cossack officer. Graduated from the Mikhailovskoye Artillery School (1904). Member of the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo–Japanese War</a>. In 1912, he graduated from the <a href="General%20Staff%20Academy%20%28Imperial%20Russia%29">Academy of the General Staff</a>. After graduating from the Academy, he commanded a <a href="Sotnia">hundred</a> in the 12th Don Cossack Regiment.
During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, he served at the headquarters of the <a href="11th%20Cavalry%20Division%20%28Russian%20Empire%29">11th Cavalry Division</a> of the 5th Cavalry Corps, and then in the Ussuri Cavalry Division. On March 1, 1916, he was awarded the <a href="Order%20of%20St.%20George">Order of Saint George</a>, 4th Degree for the distinction in battles.
From February 1917 – Chief of Staff of the Ussuri Cavalry Division. Since July 1917, he commanded the <a href="Cossacks">1st Amur Cossack Regiment</a> of the <a href="3rd%20Cavalry%20Corps%20%28Russian%20Empire%29">3rd Cavalry Corps</a> of General <a href="Aleksandr%20Krymov">Alexander Krymov</a>.
During the <a href="Kornilov%20affair">Kornilov Revolt</a>, together with the regiment, he took the side of the <a href="Russian%20Provisional%20Government">Provisional Government</a>. With this in mind, on September 17, 1917, he was appointed commander–in–chief of the troops of the <a href="Petersburg%20Military%20District%20%28Russian%20Empire%29">Petrograd Military District</a>. From September 29, 1917, after the reassignment of the district directly to the commander of the <a href="Northern%20Front%20%28Russian%20Empire%29">Northern Front</a>, he began to be called the chief of the district.
Before the <a href="October%20Revolution">October Uprising</a>, he conducted negotiations with the <a href="Military%20Revolutionary%20Committee">Petrograd Military Revolutionary Committee</a> on November 4–5. On November 7, 1917, on the eve of the uprising, he was removed by the Provisional Government from his post for "indecision" in the fight against the advancing revolution and replaced by the chief of staff, General <a href="Jaques%20Bagratuni">Yakov Bagratuni</a>.
On November 11, 1917, as the commander of the army of the <a href="Committee%20for%20the%20Salvation%20of%20the%20Homeland%20and%20Revolution">Committee for the Salvation of the Motherland and the Revolution</a>, he led the <a href="Junker%20mutiny">Cadet Action</a> in Petrograd after he had developed his plan. The revolt was suppressed the next day, November 12, 1917, by the Bolsheviks, and Polkovnikov tried to move to the <a href="Don%20Republic">Don</a>. In March 1918, he was arrested by the organs of Soviet power in the Zadonskaya Steppe and was shot by the verdict of the <a href="Revolutionary%20tribunal%20%28Russia%29">Revolutionary Tribunal</a>.
